thread.title: Corruption Currents: Fight vs. Graft Topped Americas Summit

author: Samuel Rubenfeld
title: Corruption Currents: Fight vs. Graft Topped Americas Summit
text:
0 COMMENTS The president of Peru, Martin Vizcarra, holds a press conference at the close of the VIII Summit of the Americas, in Lima on Saturday. Photo: European Pressphoto Agency 
A daily roundup of corruption news from across the Web. We also provide a daily roundup of important risk & compliance stories vi a our daily newsletter, The Morning Risk Report, which readers can sign up for here . Follow us on Twitter at @WSJRisk.
Bribery: 
An Australian engineering firm is under a foreign-bribery probe. The company said it is cooperating with investigators. (ABC)
Two former Mongolian premiers were arrested amid a probe into corrupt mining payments. The article didn’t contain comments in response. (bne)
Local cases: A former Puerto Rican lawmaker was sent to prison for bribery. Indian officials probe bribery cases . A Detroit-area trash tycoon is explaining his actions ahead of sentencing for bribery. A convicted Texas lawmaker surrendered his law license . (release, TOI, DH, MD, MD, TL, AP, EN, TPR)
Cybercrime: 
A U.S. official accused China of industrial cyber spying. (SCMP)
Islamic State was the first U.K. cyberwar target. U.K. authorities accused Russia of hacking into the email of a spy who was poisoned , and London threatened an attack on Moscow if Russia was found hacking into U.K. infrastructure. (FT, FT, NYT, Reuters)
Money Laundering: 
U.K. police lost evidence of a half-billion dollars of transactions, threats and links to a money-laundering case, according to the inquiry investigating the death of a wealthy Russian whistleblower. (Guardian, DM)
The U.K. health minister apologized after failing to declare the purchase of a luxury flat, a breach of anti-money-laundering rules. The matter was referred to ethics officials. The prime minister also earns money as a landlord, disclosures revealed. (Reuters, DM, Sun, Guardian, Guardian)
A proposed class of investors can’t revive a suit accusing Deutsche Bank of anti-money-laundering compliance failures, a court ruled . (Law360)
Securities regulators in Nepal are rolling out new anti-money-laundering requirements. (KP)
A rabbi in New Jersey who leads a special-needs school faces additional money-laundering charges. His lawyer said he vehemently denies the allegations. (APP)
A Nigerian money-laundering case continues . (DT)
Indian authorities continue pursuing money-laundering cases as they consider reform. (PTI, Hindu)
Sanctions: 
Russian lawmakers are considering a raft of countersanctions on the U.S. in the wake of Washington’s measures. Stocks are sliding on a fear of new U.S. measures. Existing measures are having their intended effect. The president has been overruled by his own aides on Russia-related matters. (MT, FT, MT, Reuters, FT, Axios, WP)
The U.S. backed off a plan to put two Chinese banks on its sanctions list for laundering North Korean money. (Bloomberg, DB)
Why is the U.S. going soft on Hezbollah? (FP)
Terrorism Finance: 
Three men pleaded guilty for secretly sending funds to Anwar al-Awlaki, an American citizen who the U.S. killed in a drone attack after he became a leader of al Qaeda in Yemen. (release)
A reputed terrorist financier attended his son’s wedding. (AN)
Transparency: 
The Panama Papers will be the subject of a new film. An Aruban official who pleaded guilty last week in the U.S. to corruption charges was exposed in the leak. (SC, MH)
Whistleblowers: 
Why do whistleblowers get treated so poorly? (SMH)
General Anti-Corruption: 
The fight against corruption was at the top of the agenda at the Summit of the Americas as many countries represented there tackled scandals . U.S. officials warned leaders to isolate Venezuela. (WP, Xinhua, AFP, WP, NYT, AP, AFP)
Pakistan barred its ousted former premier from ever again seeking political office. (FT, AJE)
Jacob Zuma‘s legacy haunts South Africa’s ruling party as the scandal continues . (ST, amabhungane)
Ukraine’s anti-corruption prosecutor has a dismal record in three years of office. He denies allegations of graft and obstruction of justice. (KP)
The U.S. special counsel’s probe continues amid questions over the future of the deputy attorney general, who is overseeing the investigation. (BuzzFeed, McClatchy, Politico, BuzzFeed)
